node.title: Smithsonian Moves Toward Returning Benin Bronzes
node.alt: The Smithsonian Institution’s National Museum of African Art in Washington is the latest Western museum, and one of the most prominent, to agree to return items that were stolen from the Kingdom of Benin more than a century ago.
node.description: The institution’s National Museum of African Art says it has removed the artworks from display. It is the latest museum to promise to repatriate the works to Nigeria.
node.content: ["The head of the Smithsonian Institution\u2019s National Museum of African Art said Friday that museum officials have removed its Benin Bronzes from display and plan to repatriate the priceless West African artifacts that were looted by the British Army more than a century ago.", "The announcement makes the Smithsonian the latest Western cultural institution \u2014 and one of the most prominent to date \u2014 to agree to return items that were stolen in 1897 from Benin City, in what is now Nigeria.", "The move was first reported by The Art Newspaper. A spokeswoman for the Smithsonian Institution confirmed the accuracy of the report but did not immediately provide any additional details.", "\u201cI can confirm that we have taken down the Benin bronzes we had on display and we are fully committed to repatriation,\u201d the museum\u2019s director, Ngaire Blankenberg, said in a statement to The Art Newspaper. \u201cWe cannot build for the future without making our best effort at healing the wounds of the past.\u201d", "Since the British Army\u2019s raid on the ancient Kingdom of Benin, thousands of items have been scattered through museums and private collections around the world. And in recent years, a movement to return the brass plaques, carved elephant tusks, ivory leopard statues and wooden heads that are collectively known as the Benin Bronzes has gained steam.", "Plans are underway to open a museum \u2014 the Edo Museum of West African Art \u2014 in Benin City as early as 2026 if enough money can be raised. The space, which is being designed by the architect David Adjaye, is expected to house at least 300 Benin Bronzes, which will come mainly from the collections of 10 major European museums.", "Nigeria\u2019s artists, historians, activists and royals have been clamoring for decades to get the pieces back. But there has been considerable resistance over the years from institutions that have at times argued that their global collections serve \u201cthe people of every nation.\u201d In Europe, where collections often belong to the state, museums sometimes insisted that they were not empowered to decide whether to return artworks.", "But in more recent years, as conversations about racism and the legacy of colonialism have proliferated, some Western museums have softened to the idea of loaning \u2014 or in some cases fully repatriating \u2014 the Benin Bronzes in their possession.", "In April, Germany said it would return a \u201csubstantial\u201d number of Benin Bronzes next year. Two months later, the Metropolitan Museum of Art announced that it would to return two brass plaques from its collection and had brokered the return of a third object that had been offered to the museum for sale."]
